full_text: A RealPage logo ois seen on a smartphone and PC screen. Some analysis suggests Austin is the city most impacted by the company's algorithmic system.Illustration by Pavlo Gonchar/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty ImagesWhen the U.S. Department of Justice sued RealPage and six of the largest rental property landlords in the nation over alleged price fixing — illegal price gouging — it came to light that Austin was among the cities where the company’s property management software had been most used.Several of the companies the Justice Department sued along with RealPage manage tens of thousands of rental units in the city. The list includes GreyStar, Camden Property Trust, Cortland Management and Willow Bridge Property Co. Agreements they have with Richardson-based Realpage likely harmed competition and pushed up rental prices, the government said in court documents.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adA Washington Post analysis identified Austin as the city most impacted, with 46% of multifamily units being managed by landlords using RealPage’s artificial intelligence-driven system.FROM JANUARY: Texas-based landlords accused of price-fixing rents, DOJ lawsuit claimsThe company says both that study and another, which ranked Austin fifth among AI rent-pricing markets, were flawed. It said the studies’ authors didn’t have the company’s data and used faulty assumptions. It hasn’t released data to substantiate that.Statesman LogoWant more Statesman?Make us a Preferred Source on Google to see more of us when you search.Add Preferred SourceBut RealPage has been adamant its software has been maligned and misunderstood.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adRichardson-based RealPage says its system is misunderstood by attorneys, states and cities that say it’s responsible for keeping rents high. The U.S. has accused it of illegal price fixing.Lola Gomez/Tribune News Service“Unfortunately, much of the debate has been fueled by serious misrepresentations about how revenue management software actually works and the value it provides for both housing providers and renters,” Jennifer Bowcock, RealPage senior vice president of communications, said in an emailed response to questions. “Related legislative activity has been animated by biased political efforts to claim quick wins.” The suit and others targeting RealPage stem from use of the company’s AI-based revenue management software, which allows landlords to share information on rents, vacancies, and other nonpublic data with each other. The software can then suggest higher rents, helping landlords present a united front rather than competing for customers through concessions or lower rents, according to the Justice Department.The company’s software — which court documents show some executives called “classic price fixing” — was popular, gobbling up 80% of the market.  AdvertisementArticle continues below this adThe company set up a website to address the criticism it’s faced since the suit and others were filed. It says increases in rental prices are caused by an undersupply of housing units and inflation, not its software and analytics.Broader impactBut now RealPage, once the toast of corporate landlords, is facing public criticism, bans in some states and former clients that say they will help the Justice Department prosecute the software giant. Many landlords have settled other cases related to their use of the system for millions of dollars.The resolution of the federal case could impact Austin’s tight housing market and what residents pay for rent.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adThen-U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland speaks with reporters in August 2024 about an antitrust lawsuit against real estate software company RealPage.Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press file photoLegal experts say it’s a bellwether case for future algorithmic price-gouging schemes in other industries, too. The use of similiar practices by hotels and health insurance providers has also been alleged. That means the outcome of the RealPage case could have wider impacts. “It’s very important,” said Bill Baer, former director of competition at the Federal Trade Commission and U.S. assistant attorney general over antitrust. “Hopefully it will return to consumers the benefit of real competition for rental apartments.”Last year the Biden Administration estimated the average additional cost to consumers of AI-price coordination was $70 per month of rent nationally, or $3.8 billion. In Dallas, it was estimated the system was costing renters $136 extra each month. It provided no specific estimate for Austin.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adBut Austin has long struggled with housing affordability. Price surges in the past decade made it one of the most costly cities to rent in. And only recently has it felt relief as rental prices fell the past two years. But it’s still nearly 17% higher than pre-pandemic levels, according to Zillow. “Lack of supply is the root cause of the housing affordability crisis,” RealPage stated on its website. In a statement they note Austin’s prices only fell when housing supply grew.What’s alleged?The Justice Department and 10 state’s attorneys general said in a 115-page civil court filing that RealPage software allowed the nation’s biggest landlords to share nonpublic data about vacancy rates, leasing prices and costs then made recommendations on how to maximize profits to the detriment of consumers. Rather than run promotions and drop prices to get customers, landlords using the software might keep apartments off the market, and prices up, or suggest higher rents in a coordinated effort.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adRealPage has denied it ever recommended keeping apartments off the market and maintains its product doesn’t break the law. RealPage collects information from its clients that lawsuits allege have kept rents high in cities including Austin.Ken Ellis/Houston Chronicle illustrationThe algorithmic-suggestions essentially took away all competition, the DOJ said, replacing the smoke-filled back rooms of old with digital databases and dashboards — and giving massive property owners plausible deniability, Baer said. “It gives the companies who submit data and get back recommended pricing … [the ability to say] ‘Well, I didn’t do it, The algorithm just did it. It’s just math. It’s not collusion,’ ” he said. “No, it’s using an algorithm to collude.”AdvertisementArticle continues below this adCortland Management settled with the government in January over its 80,000 units. Greystar, which owns and manages nearly a million units in the United States also settled  two months ago for $50 million. It said it wouldn’t share the sensitive, nonpublic data again or use such algorithms, and that it will help the government’s prosecution of RealPage. Companies that settled with the government are helping the government’s case, Baer said. “They have provided very incriminating evidence that this kind of collusion was intentional and was happening a whole lot,” he said. That isn’t the only bad news for the $10 billion company. Cities in multiple states have banned the use of AI-rent setting and 22 states have considered or are considering legislation banning software like RealPage. New York — the only state to have passed a law — signed it into effect last month.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adIn September, RealPage settled with the state of Nevada. It made no admission of wrongdoing and was able to continue using nonpublic data to generate rent recommendations as long as they were based on data that was three-months old and anonymized.The company is fighting back, too. It sued the city of Berkeley, Calif., over its ordinance banning the software, saying it was “prompted by an intentional campaign of misinformation and often-repeated false claims about the company’s revenue management software.”Austin rentsAustin rents have been declining for more than a year after an apartment building boom increased supply and drove down prices. But rents are still high enought that, according to a Harvard University study last year, more than half of the region’s renters are cost burdened — meaning they’re spending more than 30% of their income on housing. AdvertisementArticle continues below this adThe U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development estimated that the fair market rental rate for an efficiency in the Austin-Round Rock metropolitan statistical area in 2015 was $681. In 2025 it was $1,549 — an increase of 127%. According to the Justice’s Department’s complaint, RealPage is designed to keep rents artificially high regardless of market forces. Court documents imply markets like Austin that have seen some relief on rents, may have been more affordable without RealPage’s involvement. Quoted in court documents, RealPage information appears to support that assertion: “Our tool … ensures that [landlords] are driving every possible opportunity to increase price even in the most downward trending or unexpected conditions.”  K Agbebiyi, senior housing campaign coordinator at the Private Equity Stakeholder Project, said its data shows that rents for the poorest residents have been affected more than those for other economic groups. AdvertisementArticle continues below this ad“It’s going to be the poorer tenants that are largely hit by these rent prices,” they said.Online tools allow would-be renters to search for aparements and rental rates.AndreyPopov/Getty ImagesBut Agdebiyi rejected the idea that simply banning RealPage would reverse rising housing prices. While the organization has said RealPage is harmful to the rental landscape, it agrees the company has been scapegoated. That’s because the issues of affordability go far beyond RealPage’s control, including the rise of private equity in rental markets, the project says. But RealPage is an easier target for people to understand, they said. “I think instead it’s easier for states to be like, ‘Oh, well, rent is really high because of this, like, boogie man,’ " Agdebiyi said of cities and states that are going after the company.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adAI-fueled gougingRent rates are not the only costs for which AI-price gouging has been alleged. The Justice Department has said the use of algorithmic technologies used by competitors to coordinate decision making “poses a growing threat to the free market.”“It’s not limited to the rental housing market,” Baer, the former Justice Department official, said. “The fact is it may well be that this is just the tip of the iceberg.”  The department says, for example, that a company called MultiPlan Inc is using such tools to drive down the amount it reimburses health providers for services. It says hotels are doing it to drive up prices in Las Vegas. Researchers have found AI-collusion in the financial markets. And the Federal Trade Commission is investigating surveillance pricing — the practice of using intimate details about individual consumers to set prices, changing the price of goods and services based on browser history or an individual’s financial information.AdvertisementArticle continues below this adHow the case against RealPage ends will have a significant impact on future attempts by the government to rein in AI’s influence on such costs of living. Baer said the idea of a world where each purchase price is set based on what individuals can spend is not far-fetched. “It’s not. It requires oversight by the government to make sure markets are not becoming increasingly anti-competitive,” he said. “And companies need to have the internal controls to make sure they aren’t inadvertently, or perhaps intentionally, getting into a price fixing scheme.”AdvertisementArticle continues below this ad
